definitions.definition: to walk with stiff regular steps like a soldier

examples.text: Quick march! *(= the order to start marching)*
Soldiers were marching up and down outside the government buildings.
They marched 20 miles to reach the capital.

definitions.definition: to walk somewhere quickly in a determined way

examples.text: She marched over to me and demanded an apology.
Craig marched up to the door and rang the bell.
So saying, she marched boldly out of the house.
Ann marched straight past me and up the stairs.
They marched proudly onto the football field.

definitions.definition: to walk through the streets in a large group in order to protest about something

examples.text: Millions of people marched against the war.
We marched peacefully through the streets.
Hundreds of people marched in support of the teachers' pay claim.

definitions.definition: to force somebody to walk somewhere with you

examples.text: The guards marched the prisoner away.
She was marched out of the door and into a waiting car.

definitions.definition: to be ordered to leave a place, a job, etc.
to order somebody to leave a place, their job, etc.
to behave in a different way from other people; to have different attitudes or ideas

examples.text: She was a gifted and original artist who marched to a different drummer.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from French marcher ‘to walk’ (earlier ‘to trample’), of uncertain origin.
